title: Variant Rules
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:a,jsxs:n}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(t){const r={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",h3:"h3",p:"p",strong:"strong",...t.components};return n(e,{children:[a(r.h1,{children:"Variant Rules"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"If your playgroup likes extra little tactical nuggets, your GM can allow you to try out some of these additional variants to add some more spice to your game. You can always try out a rule for 1 session and see how you all like it before committing to it."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Multiclassing"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"If your GM wants to allow for additional creativity for experienced players (and potentially broken combos!), when heroes level up, they may choose any class. For example, when a level 4 Berserker levels up, he could pick Commander, and take the level 1 Commander features instead of the level 5 Berserker features. He would have 4 d12 hit dice and a single d10 hit die. A hero gains all the equipment proficiencies of all their classes but should use the advantaged/disadvantaged saves of whichever class has the highest level."}),"
",n(r.blockquote,{children:["
",a(r.p,{children:'"Broken" Can Be Fun!
Planning, building, optimizing, and “breaking” a class build IS the fun for many people. The GM may need to make the game substantially more challenging if multiclassing is allowed. The GM also may veto any particularly overpowered, unfun, or implausible combo for the sake of the story and overall fun of the table. If this happens, well done! Your hero was too powerful for reality.'}),"
"]}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Small Groups"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"A GM and a single hero can play with the aid of a sidekick. Sidekicks are NPCs that the hero’s player controls during combat and the GM controls outside of combat. Sidekicks get 2 actions and are always 1 level below the hero character. If the main hero dies, the sidekick can be upgraded 1 level, and hire his own sidekick to keep the adventure going! A GM can optionally allow one or two sidekicks with a party of 2-3 heroes as well."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Large Groups"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"3rd party adventures are typically balanced for parties of 3-5 players. Playing with very large groups (6–10+ heroes) can be made far more manageable simply by limiting each hero’s actions to 2 instead of 3. No other rebalancing needs to be done."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Fast Resting"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"For a much more heroic and fast-paced story, a Safe Rest can heal all Wounds."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Critical Healing"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Treat healing just like an attack roll. Rolling the max is a crit (rolling again just like an attack crit), rolling 1 is a failure to heal (note: this variant is FUN for the right group that enjoys big, dramatic, swingy moments). Consider increment the die size by one step if you use this variant (d4 » d6 » d8 » d10 » d12)."}),"
",n(r.h3,{children:["I ",a(r.strong,{children:"Had"})," the High Ground"]}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Taking a crit while at a height may cause a character to fall down. A reasonable STR save may be called for, but a weak character (e.g., a kobold) may just fall automatically."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Thrown Potions"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Treat potions like Ranged attacks (Range 8). The potion misses on a 1; otherwise it heals for half as much since some splashes away and is wasted."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Sucker Punch"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"A character standing up from Prone gives adjacent enemies the chance to take opportunity attacks (heroes and monsters alike)."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Playing Dead"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Whenever a Hero drops to 0 HP, they can attempt to play dead by falling prone and making an Influence check (or other skill check as the situation demands)."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Inspiration"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Whenever a hero does something memorable (role-plays a great moment, makes everyone laugh, miss an attack multiple times in a row, or otherwise engages in desired behavior), the GM can grant Inspiration: the ability to reroll any single die. Inspiration expires after a Safe Rest."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Retreat"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"The world is dangerous, and some fights may be unwinnable. Any hero may call for a retreat on their turn. If the party agrees—unless there is a good reason story-wise that a party can’t escape (e.g., they are trapped in nets and completely surrounded by a band of nasty kobolds)—the GM allows them to flee. Each hero describes their escape (e.g., casting a spell, using equipment, or making a skill check). Consequences may follow, such as taking damage, suffering a Wound, or failing a quest. If the escape is particularly clever, the GM may allow the party to escape without additional consequence. After all, the shame of retreating is often punishment enough!"}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Different Key Stats"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"Players can swap KEY or Secondary stats for a class if it makes sense (e.g., DEX and WIL for the Cheat)."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Complex Characters"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"A GM may allow heroes to pick 2 backgrounds and/or ancestry bonuses."}),"
",a(r.h3,{children:"Custom Weapon Dice"}),"
",a(r.p,{children:"For larger weapon die sizes, you can try using dice of a different size as long as they add up to the same initial die size. For example: a 1d10 glaive could be 1d4+1d6 or 1d6+1d4 (using the first die as the primary die)."})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:n}=e.components||{};return n?a(n,{...e,children:a(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

title: Wealth
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:r,jsxs:n}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(t){const l={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",h3:"h3",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",table:"table",tbody:"tbody",td:"td",th:"th",thead:"thead",tr:"tr",ul:"ul",...t.components};return n(e,{children:[r(l.h1,{children:"Wealth"}),"
",r(l.h3,{children:"Gold & Currency"}),"
",r(l.p,{children:"Gold is a versatile reward that gives heroes the freedom to choose their own rewards. While some gold will be spent on necessities like lodging, its primary appeal is to purchase exciting upgrades: better weapons, armor, potions, wands, or magical items."}),"
",r(l.p,{children:"Currency is made up of Silver (sp) and Gold pieces (gp). 10 silver = 1 gold. 1 sp is roughly the cost of a humble meal; 1 gp, a sumptuous feast. Most small towns will have equipment and items worth 50 gp or less. You’ll need to adventure to larger towns or cities or find a traveling merchant to purchase more valuable pieces of equipment."}),"
",r(l.h3,{children:"How Much Gold?"}),"
",r(l.p,{children:"This table outlines the average amount of gold each hero will typically gain per level. A quest for a noble cause or from a poor villager might pay modestly (one or two levels below average), while one from a wealthy noble with questionable motives may offer a more extravagant reward (one or two levels above average)."}),"
",n(l.blockquote,{children:["
",r(l.p,{children:"Gold Gain Per Level"}),"
"]}),"
",n(l.table,{children:[r(l.thead,{children:n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.th,{children:"LEVEL"}),r(l.th,{children:"GOLD"})]})}),n(l.tbody,{children:[n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"1"}),r(l.td,{children:"25"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"2"}),r(l.td,{children:"40"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"3"}),r(l.td,{children:"80"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"4"}),r(l.td,{children:"150"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"5"}),r(l.td,{children:"280"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"6"}),r(l.td,{children:"450"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"7"}),r(l.td,{children:"750"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"8"}),r(l.td,{children:"1,200"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"9"}),r(l.td,{children:"2,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"10"}),r(l.td,{children:"3,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"11"}),r(l.td,{children:"5,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"12"}),r(l.td,{children:"7,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"13"}),r(l.td,{children:"10,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"14"}),r(l.td,{children:"17,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"15"}),r(l.td,{children:"25,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"16"}),r(l.td,{children:"40,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"17"}),r(l.td,{children:"60,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"18"}),r(l.td,{children:"90,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"19"}),r(l.td,{children:"130,000"})]}),n(l.tr,{children:[r(l.td,{children:"20"}),r(l.td,{children:"200,000"})]})]})]}),"
",r(l.h3,{children:"On Buying Magical Items"}),"
",r(l.p,{children:"Most adventurers can save up enough to purchase uncommon or rare magical items, often found in specialty shops in large cities. However, very rare or legendary items are typically far too expensive to buy and must be earned through adventuring."}),"
",r(l.h3,{children:"Too Much Gold?"}),"
",r(l.p,{children:"An overabundance of gold has its challenges and it may attract unwanted attention:"}),"
",n(l.ul,{children:["
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"It’s Cumbersome."})," You can only carry so much gold before your pockets and bags are full. Large amounts must be transported via caravan or ship and safely stored somewhere while adventuring."]}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Bandits & Thieves."})," Pickpockets, ambushers, and even organized crime may want a cut."]}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Jealousy."}),' Rival adventurers, "old money" nobles, resentful poor, debt collectors, etc.']}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Corruption."}),' Government looking for bribes, fake "opportunities," suspicious authorities.']}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Curses."})," A cache of gold or jewels cursed by dark magic, greedy spirits, or treasure guardians."]}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Fame."})," Opportunists, sycophants, bounty hunters, or warlords all may want a cut."]}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"People In Need."})," A destitute village, public works projects, beggars, allies in need."]}),"
",n(l.li,{children:[r(l.strong,{children:"Greedy Monsters."})," Dragons and other powerful beings are drawn to large hoards of gold."]}),"
"]})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:n}=e.components||{};return n?r(n,{...e,children:r(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

title: 5e Conversion
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:n,jsxs:t}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(r){const i={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",h3:"h3",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...r.components};return t(e,{children:[n(i.h1,{children:"5e Conversion"}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Adventures"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"You can run any 5e compatible adventure right out of the book with no additional prep and minimal changes. For the skills, saves, and conditions that were combined or changed, just use the updated name."}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Saving Throws"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"CON save -> STR save
WIS/CHA save -> WIL save"}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Skill Checks"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"Animal Handling/Nature/Survival -> Naturecraft
Athletics -> Might
Deception/Persuasion/Performance -> Influence
History/Religion -> Lore
Investigation/Medicine -> Examination
Sleight of Hand/Acrobatics -> Finesse"}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Conditions"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"Paralyzed, Stunned, Unconscious -> Incapacitated"}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Monsters"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"You can likewise use any 5e compatible monster stat block with Nimble with minimal tweaks on the fly. Run them exactly as written, using their move, action, bonus action, etc. as normal; simply change their AC to armor and roll their damage dice for attacks."}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Monster Attacks."})," They miss, hit, and crit just like heroes."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Monster Armor."})," 5e monsters that have ",n(i.strong,{children:"14–17 AC have Medium Armor"}),", less than that is unarmored, more than that is Heavy."]}),"
"]}),"
",t(i.blockquote,{children:["
",n(i.p,{children:"A Note on Armor
Encounter balance in Nimble is much more forgiving than other games. A GM can adjust armor up or down quite freely without breaking encounter balance. If too many monsters have the same AC, the GM can upgrade/downgrade their armor for variety. Unarmored should be the bulk of monsters your party encounters (~60%), Medium should be uncommon (only about 30% of the monsters in any given session), while Heavy should be quite rare (~10%)."}),"
"]}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"5e Legendary Monsters"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"Nimble Legendary monsters will be much easier to run and provide a more dynamic experience, but you can run 5e legendary monsters as written just like other monsters! Change their AC to armor and simply roll their damage dice for attacks. They act 1/round (using their Lair / Legendary Actions as normal in 5e)."}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Optional Tweaks"}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Monster Saves."})," To simplify play, roll a d20 for saves without bonuses. If a monster is notably Strong/Frail, Fast/Slow, or Smart/Dumb, give them advantage or disadvantage on their STR, DEX, or WIL/INT saves. Legendary monsters may have advantage on multiple or all saves."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Player Agency."})," When a monster would take away agency in some way from heroes (incapacitate, paralyze, petrify, or stun), consider the new Dazed condition instead (–1 action for 1 round)."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"5e Spells"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"Most 5e spells should be easy enough to use with Nimble without any change. Though it’s not recommended to use 5e combat-related spells, some of the more unique utility spells could make the game more interesting. Use common sense, but here are some rules of thumb:"}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",n(i.li,{children:"The spell’s level is how much mana it costs. Range is shorter in Nimble (typically 16 spaces/80 ft. max)"}),"
",t(i.li,{children:["Cantrips, Bonus Action, Reaction, or other simple, non-damaging spells cost ",n(i.strong,{children:"1 Action"}),"; other leveled spells cost ",n(i.strong,{children:"2 Actions"}),", large AoE spells that can be cast from a distance cost ",n(i.strong,{children:"3 Actions"}),"."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"5e Magical Items"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"For items that change stats, simply use the ability score modifier."}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"5e Races & Classes"}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Race & Background:"})," Pick a Nimble ancestry and background and flavor them however you like."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Classes:"})," For the smoothest experience, it is recommended to use a Nimble class; however, you can use any 5e-compatible class. Simply swap in the Nimble attack and armor rules. Don’t attempt to mix and match 5e and Nimble spells, feats, or other options; stick with one or the other. See the Nimble 5e booklet for more."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(i.h3,{children:"Monster Skill Checks"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:"If a contested skill check is ever desired or necessary, since Nimble monsters don’t have skills or stats, you can roll an additional die based on the creature’s capabilities and add it to the skill check instead:"}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"No bonus or +1d4."})," This monster is untrained or average at this skill."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"+1d6–1d10."})," This monster is trained or very good in the skill."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"+1d12–1d20."})," This monster is world class or has legendary capability with this skill."]}),"
"]})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:t}=e.components||{};return t?n(t,{...e,children:n(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

title: Combat Encounter Guidelines
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:n,jsxs:r}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(t){const o={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",h3:"h3",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...t.components};return r(e,{children:[n(o.h1,{children:"Combat Encounter Guidelines"}),"
",n(o.h1,{children:"Monster Levels"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"Making encounters in Nimble is easy! Simply add up the total levels of the heroes (e.g., if you have 3 level 2 heroes, their total is 6). Monsters with a total level equal to that will be a hard but fair fight; less than that: medium or easy; greater than that: deadly, or very deadly."}),"
",r(o.blockquote,{children:["
",n(o.p,{children:"Example
A griffon is a level 4 monster. So a flock of 6 griffons (24 monster levels total) would be a hard encounter for: 6 level 4 heroes, 4 level 6 heroes, or 3 level 8 heroes."}),"
"]}),"
",r(o.p,{children:["Typical encounters should have ",n(o.strong,{children:"1–4 monsters per hero"})," (excluding minions). For an epic fight against a single bad guy, use a legendary monster, and if you want hordes of monsters, use minions."]}),"
",r(o.blockquote,{children:["
",n(o.p,{children:"Important Note!
If the heroes or monsters greatly outnumber one another the encounter may be easier or harder than anticipated. 1–4 monsters per hero is the sweet spot for most encounters."}),"
"]}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Encounters Per Rest"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"Typically, a session includes 2–5 combat encounters, but this is flexible. If your players are enjoying the game without combat, don’t force it—especially if they’ve cleverly avoided it or it doesn’t fit the story. If the story calls for more than five encounters, go ahead! The key is to ensure the game remains fun and engaging—avoiding encounters that are trivial, frustratingly difficult, or repetitive."}),"
",n(o.h1,{children:"Encounter Difficulties"}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Easy"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"If the monster’s total levels are less than half of the heroes’, this is an easy encounter. Heroes will lose minimal HP and resources, making these encounters great for testing new abilities or gauging progress—or whittling down resources. They help players feel powerful, especially after leveling up. Use 1–2 easy encounters in a typical session."}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Medium"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"When the monster’s levels are around 75% of the heroes’, expect some HP loss and moderate resource expenditure. Heroes will get hurt but shouldn’t drop to 0 HP. Use 1–2 medium encounters in a typical session."}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Hard"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"When the monster’s levels equal the heroes’, this encounter will be challenging but fair. Heroes must use significant resources; some may drop to 0 HP, but none should die, barring poor tactics or bad luck. Use 1 hard encounter in a typical session."}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Deadly"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"When monster levels are 100–125% of the heroes’, this encounter requires strategic thinking and teamwork. Suitable for tough battles, well-equipped parties, or campaign bosses. Use sparingly!"}),"
",n(o.h3,{children:"Very Deadly"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"At 150%+ monster levels, this encounter is extremely dangerous. Unless they are extremely well optimized (or are multiclassing) and play exquisitely, they will almost certainly need to retreat—or die. Use only when the heroes made a bad mistake: you telegraphed danger and they fail to heed."}),"
",n(o.h1,{children:"Resting and Recovery"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"It’s common for heroes to return to a home base or town to rest after each session, but this isn’t a rule. Be adaptable. If your players are accumulating too many Wounds, consider introducing an opportunity for a Safe Rest, such as finding a friendly cleric or a hidden oasis. If a Safe Rest isn’t an option, you can ease the encounter difficulty to keep the adventure moving. Otherwise, heroes might need to cut their journey short to recover."}),"
",n(o.h1,{children:"Armor Variety"}),"
",n(o.p,{children:"While these ratios can vary, too many armored foes can bog down combat. Use armor to add flavor, not frustration. For a balanced session, aim for roughly:"}),"
",r(o.ul,{children:["
",n(o.li,{children:n(o.strong,{children:"60% Unarmored."})}),"
",n(o.li,{children:n(o.strong,{children:"30% Medium Armor."})}),"
",n(o.li,{children:n(o.strong,{children:"10% Heavy Armor."})}),"
"]})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:r}=e.components||{};return r?n(r,{...e,children:n(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

title: Fine Tuning Difficulty
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:n,jsxs:t}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(i){const r={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",h3:"h3",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",table:"table",tbody:"tbody",td:"td",th:"th",thead:"thead",tr:"tr",ul:"ul",...i.components};return t(e,{children:[n(r.h1,{children:"Fine Tuning Difficulty"}),"
",t(r.p,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Start Easy."}),'
Creating perfectly balanced encounters takes practice. It’s better to err on the side of "too easy" than "too hard." As a GM, you have many ways to increase difficulty during play, but few ways to lower it without breaking immersion.']}),"
",n(r.h3,{children:"Balancing With Tactics"}),"
",t(r.ul,{children:["
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Focus Fire."})," Concentrating attacks on one or two heroes makes encounters feel harder. Conversely, spreading out damage or sending monsters in waves can make the encounter more manageable."]}),"
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Movement."})," Monsters that move each turn force martial characters to reposition, limiting their attacks. This also opens up opportunities for reactions like Opportunity Attacks. To lower difficulty, reduce monster movement."]}),"
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Target Squishy Characters."})," Make them use their actions to defend or run away and hide behind their stronger friends! Let the tanks feel good about Defending and Interposing."]}),"
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Adjust Initiative."})," The sooner the monsters act in the round, the harder the encounter will be, and vice versa. If, after the first player’s turn, it looks like the bad guys are in for a trouncing, move some of them up in the initiative order instead of waiting until the end of the round."]}),"
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Relax!"})," Heroes have plenty of tools to handle tough situations, so don’t stress over getting every encounter perfectly balanced. You’ll improve with experience, as will your players."]}),"
",t(r.li,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Hero Death Isn’t the End."})," If some (or all) heroes die, it’s not necessarily a failure. Encourage your group to make new characters and dive back in."]}),"
"]}),"
",n(r.h3,{children:"Balancing with Minions"}),"
",n(r.p,{children:"Minions excel as battlefield filler, allowing heroes to showcase their strengths. Armored defenders can hold off waves of attacks, while spellcasters can annihilate groups with a single spell. They help combat feel dynamic and give heroes the chance to shine, all while keeping the pace fast and exciting."}),"
",t(r.p,{children:[n(r.strong,{children:"Waves of Minions."}),"
Start with an easier encounter and introduce minions in waves to dial in the challenge. Minions might emerge from hidden positions or be summoned mid-battle."]}),"
",t(r.ul,{children:["
",n(r.li,{children:"1 minion/hero: Slightly more difficult, but will greatly increase the tactical options."}),"
",n(r.li,{children:"2–3 minions/hero: Noticeably more difficult."}),"
",n(r.li,{children:"4 minions per hero: Much more challenging."}),"
"]}),"
",t(r.blockquote,{children:["
",n(r.p,{children:"Overkill Damage
While minions lack HP, you can optionally use their die size as a measure of durability. Excess damage from an attack can carry over to other minions in range. For example, a 20 damage attack could take down two d10 minions or five d4 minions."}),"
"]}),"
",n(r.h3,{children:"Suggested minion die size by party level"}),"
",t(r.table,{children:[n(r.thead,{children:t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.th,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"Level"}),n(r.th,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"Die Size"})]})}),t(r.tbody,{children:[t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"1-3"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d4"})]}),t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"3-5"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d6"})]}),t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"5-10"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d8"})]}),t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"10-13"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d10"})]}),t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"13-17"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d12"})]}),t(r.tr,{children:[n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"17-20"}),n(r.td,{style:{textAlign:"center"},children:"d20"})]})]})]})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:t}=e.components||{};return t?n(t,{...e,children:n(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

title: Flavorful Monster Abilities
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:n,jsxs:t}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(r){const i={h1:"h1",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...r.components};return t(e,{children:[n(i.h1,{children:"Flavorful Monster Abilities"}),"
",n(i.p,{children:'Once you have the base stats for the encounter, you can optionally add a cool flavorful ability to make these monsters feel and play differently. Abilities can be passive or trigger "On Movement," "On Attack," "On Miss," "On Hit," "On Damage," "On Crit," "On Death," and more.'}),"
",t(i.ul,{children:["
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Acid Blood."})," Melee attackers take half the HP lost in return as acid damage."]}),"
",t(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Aggressive."})," +X speed if moving toward enemies."]}),"

",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Advantage X."})," Roll X additional dice and drop the X lowest dice (removing dice from the left to right in the case of a tie)."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Ally."})," A friendly creature, not yourself."]}),"

",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Falling."})," Suffer 1d6 damage per 10 ft. fallen."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Field Rest/Safe Rest."})," Spend time to recover some of your resources."]}),"

",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Knockback/Push X."})," Forcibly move a creature X spaces, ignoring Difficult Terrain. Other creatures or the environment may halt movement prematurely and deal damage."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Line X."})," A straight line extending up to X spaces in one direction."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"LVL."})," Replace this with your Hero’s level."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Mana."})," Used to fuel spellcasting. See the Heroes book for more info on how classes gain mana."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Move X."})," Move up to that many spaces."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Paralyzed, Stunned, Unconscious."})," Incapacitated. Can’t do anything. Attacks against you have advantage, and melee attacks that hit, crit."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Reach X."})," The area within X spaces around a character; forming your choice of a cube or sphere."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Range X."})," Ranged attacks are made with disadvantage if ANY enemy is adjacent. Range can be extended."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Resistance."})," Take half as much damage."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Restrained."})," Same effect as Grappled, objects Restrain, creatures Grapple."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Round."})," The time in combat when each Hero and enemy has a chance to act."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Rushed Attacks."})," Attacking more than once on a turn imposes a cumulative disadvantage penalty (e.g., attacking with a short sword for the third time on a turn, you would roll 3d6 and take the lowest result)."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Skill Points."})," Use them to increase your skills. Start with 4 at level 1 and gain 1 each level."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Spellcasting Focus."})," Can be used instead of an empty hand to cast spells."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Stats."})," The core attributes of a character."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Surprise."})," When combat starts before all sides are aware."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Target."})," A selected creature or object. It must be within Range/Reach and able to be sensed."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Teleport."})," Move instantaneously. Does not provoke opportunity attacks."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Temp HP."})," HP that do not replenish."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Turn."})," The primary time allotted for an individual hero or monster group to act."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Unheld."})," Not touched, worn, or held by anyone."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Vulnerable."})," When a creature is vulnerable to a damage type, that kind of damage ignores its armor; if unarmored, they take double the damage instead."]}),"
",r(i.li,{children:[n(i.strong,{children:"Wound."})," A measure of how close a hero is to death. Typically 6 and you’re dead."]}),"
"]})]})}return{default:function(e={}){const{wrapper:r}=e.components||{};return r?n(r,{...e,children:n(_createMdxContent,{...e})}):_createMdxContent(e)}};

",e(a.p,{children:"Your hero is how you will make your mark on the world. Here’s how you can make your own hero:"}),"
",e(a.h2,{children:"Step 1: Choose Your Class"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"This will have the largest impact on the other character choices you make and how you interact with the world:"}),"
",r(a.ul,{children:["
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"BERSERKER."})," An unstoppable force of wrath and ruin."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"THE CHEAT."})," Sneaky, backstabbing, dirty-fighting rogue."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"COMMANDER."})," A battlefield tactician, leader, and weapon master."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"HUNTER."})," Resourceful survivalist, bow master, and skilled tracker."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"MAGE."})," Wield and shape the elements of fire, ice, and lightning."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"OATHSWORN."})," Faithful guardian, protector, and avenger of the weak."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"SHADOWMANCER."})," Summon hordes of expendable minions."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"SHEPHERD."})," Master life and death. Lead a faithful companion."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"SONGWEAVER."})," Inspiring presence, sharp wit, sharper tongue."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"STORMSHIFTER."})," Master of weather, beast, and nature."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"ZEPHYR."})," A disciplined martial artist with swift hands and swift feet."]}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.h2,{children:"Step 2: Choose Your Ancestry & Background"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"(and optionally, choose your adventuring motivation). What made your hero want to start adventuring? How do you know the other heroes?"}),"
",e(a.h2,{children:"Step 3: Fill in Your Character Sheet"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"This handy sheet of paper helps you track your stats, abilities, loot, and other important game info."}),"
",e(a.h1,{children:"The Character Sheet"}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"1. Basic Details & Stats"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"Fill in your character details: Name, Ancestry, Class, Level, Height, and Weight. Fill in the arrow for your advantaged (+) and disadvantaged (–) Saves, and choose a stat array (recommended: place the highest numbers in the KEY stats for your class)."}),"
",r(a.ul,{children:["
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Standard:"})," +2, +2, +0, –1"]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Balanced:"})," +2, +1, +1, +0"]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Min–Max:"})," +3, +1, –1, –1"]}),"
"]}),"
",r(a.blockquote,{children:["
",e(a.p,{children:"Example
The Cheat has DEX and INT as their KEY stats. With the Min-Max array, you might put +3 in DEX, +1 in INT, and –1 in WIL and STR. You’d also mark ▲ for DEX saves and ▼ for WIL saves."}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"2. Skill Points"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"At level 1, mark your stat bonuses into each of your respective skills (e.g., a hero with +2 DEX would mark +2 in Finesse and Stealth), and then may place 4 additional skill points wherever you like."}),"
",r(a.blockquote,{children:["
",e(a.p,{children:"Example
If you have –1 INT; mark –1 for Arcana, Examination, and Lore. Repeat for your other stats. Then, with your 4 extra points, you could increase Stealth and Finesse by +2 each; any 4 skills by 1 each; or dump all 4 points into your favorite single skill. Up to you!"}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"3. Secondary Stats"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"Mark your max HP and Hit Dice size (see your class), Hit Die amount (default: equal to your level), Initiative (default: DEX), Size, Speed (default: 6), max Wounds (default: 6), and inventory slots (10+STR)."}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"4. Equipment & Money"}),"
",r(a.p,{children:["Heroes start at level 1 with the equipment listed for their class and background OR ",e(a.strong,{children:"50 gp"})," to buy their starting equipment. If starting at a higher level, multiply that by the level you are starting at."]}),"
",r(a.blockquote,{children:["
",e(a.p,{children:"But my character is a wealthy noble!
That’s fine, but your character only has access to this amount of gold for now. Why your wealth is currently inaccessible is up to you and your GM; unlocking your full riches could be a great quest!"}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"5. Languages"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"All heroes speak Common by default. Each point of INT grants you an additional language known. These languages are typically spoken by:"}),"
",r(a.ul,{children:["
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Common."})," Most intelligent creatures."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Dwarvish."})," Dwarves, Gnomes, and Giants."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Elvish."})," Elves, Fey, and Sylvan."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Goblin."})," Goblins and Orcs."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Infernal."})," Various Fiends and cultists."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Thieves’ Cant."})," Scoundrels and rogues."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Celestial."})," Celestials and priests."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Draconic."})," Dragons, Dragonborn, and Kobolds."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Primordial."})," Elementals and Ancient Beings."]}),"
",r(a.li,{children:[e(a.strong,{children:"Deep Speak."})," Underworld dwellers."]}),"
"]}),"
",r(a.blockquote,{children:["
",e(a.p,{children:"GROFWINT DRAZLON!
Speaking another creature’s language can open doors that weapons alone cannot—being heavily armed without the ability to communicate often leads to hostility."}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"6. Other Abilities"}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"Mark any other special abilities you get from your class, ancestry, background, etc."}),"
",e(a.h3,{children:"7. Inventory Slots"}),"
",r(a.p,{children:["Each hero has ",e(a.strong,{children:"10+STR"})," inventory slots for carrying equipment and loot (held, worn, or in a pack)."]}),"
",r(a.ul,{children:["
",e(a.li,{children:"1 slot can hold a one-handed weapon, shield, worn armor, stack of javelins, 500 gp, or 2 potions."}),"
",e(a.li,{children:"2 slots can hold a 2-handed weapon, unworn armor, or similarly bulky items."}),"
",e(a.li,{children:"Small, related items can be grouped into one slot for simplicity (e.g., Camping Supplies: soap, blanket, brush, rations)."}),"
"]}),"
",r(a.blockquote,{children:["
",e(a.p,{children:"On Ammunition.
In most games, there’s no need to track ammo. If you have a quiver, you have enough arrows. Assume the hero collects fired arrows, crafts more, or buys them in town."}),"
"]}),"
",e(a.p,{children:"Alternatively, your GM may allow you to carry what you want without the bookkeeping, so long as you’re reasonable!"})]})}return{default:function(n={}){const{wrapper:r}=n.components||{};return r?e(r,{...n,children:e(_createMdxContent,{...n})}):_createMdxContent(n)}};

title: Unique Encounters
content:
const{Fragment:e,jsx:t,jsxs:n}=arguments[0];function _createMdxContent(r){const a={blockquote:"blockquote",h1:"h1",li:"li",p:"p",strong:"strong",ul:"ul",...r.components};return n(e,{children:[t(a.h1,{children:"Unique Encounters"}),"
",t(a.p,{children:"Most encounters start with heroes and bad guys aware of each other, within one or two moves apart, and feature 1–4 level-appropriate enemies per hero who fight to the death. While this formula works, changing it up from time to time can make for a more memorable encounter. Here are some ways to spice things up:"}),"
",n(a.ul,{children:["
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Ambush (Bad Guys)!"})," A easy encounter becomes much more difficult and exciting when the bad guys get the drop on the heroes. Place hidden enemies close to the party, and let them act first (just be careful that there is a good story reason for the ambush or you give them a chance to spot it!)."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Ambush (Heroes)!"})," An extremely hard encounter, but the heroes get plenty of time to scout, research weaknesses, set up traps and obstacles, or even choose the battleground (on top of getting a full turn to act before the bad guys can act)."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Backdraft."})," Heroes take damage whenever they take a certain action (e.g., cast spells, use weapons, move, or use special abilities)."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Betrayal!"})," Have an allied NPC suddenly turn on the heroes mid-fight (temporarily or permanently)."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Can’t Reach Me!"})," Where a relatively weak group of bad guys are at an unfairly advantageous height, and able to drop heavy things onto the heroes. Or out of range of melee attacks from the heroes and with excellent cover against range."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Capture the Flag."})," The heroes must take (and keep) possession of an item that the bad guys desperately want."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Charmed Allies."})," Enemies cast powerful charms or illusions on one or more party members, forcing the heroes to fight their own while trying to break the spell."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Defend the Fort."})," Heroes must defend a location for a certain number of rounds until reinforcements arrive."]}),"
",n(a.li,{children:[t(a.strong,{children:"Divided Loyalties."})," Two enemy factions are fighting each other when the heroes arrive. The party can choose to sit back and let the factions weaken each other, manipulate the chaos to their advantage, or attack both sides."]}),"
